elements.text: [Part One]
Come on. Aren't the acoustic reflectors in place yet?
Almost there, Lomas.
Do hurry up, Bix, I haven't got all night. We're losing the light as it is. Pay attention, please, everyone. I intend to begin the first recital in just a few moments, so places please.
6: (robotic) Test pattern shows optimum function on all peripherals, Senor Alloran.
Very good, Familiar Six. Merickson, that coupling looks loose. See to it. Familiar Twelve ?
12: (they all sound the same) Your wish, Sefor Alloran?
Assist Sefor Merickson with that coupling.
12: Yes, Sefor Alloran.

Can we have quiet, please? Please, quiet! Main power on. My friends, we couldn't have asked for a more beautiful evening. The sunset, the fading light against the city walls. From this distance perhaps we could be forgiven for imagining it to be a place of harmony, rather than a place of waste and suffering.
Applause.
The core processor is now voicing.

Thank you. Everyone, you all know how I've struggled these last months to get to this point. I've tried to remain committed in the face of criticism and scorn. Each one of you has helped me in ways I can't possibly repay, except to let you share in this. I will begin the first recital.
Sound builds, thunder.

Yes. Yes, you can hear the theme develop. It's finding character, expression. That's it. Bring up the second bank of resonators. (rumbles.) Good. Oh, listen to it. Immortal sounds. Primal sounds. (glass breaking) What was that?
6: Several lamps have failed in the lighting gantry, Sefor Alloran.
Replace them at once, Familiar Six.
6: Yes, Sefor Alloran.
Bring up bank three. Bix, adjust the harmonisers.
Yes, Lomas.
Where the hell are those damn lights?
6: There are no lamp spares in the supply vehicle, Senor Alloran.
What? Find some.
6: There are no lamp spares in...
For glory's sake, Familiar Six. Autonomous function. Procure me some replacements.
6: Autonomous function confirmed, Sefor Alloran. I will attend to your needs.
Thunder.
By the heavens. This is magnificent!
Lomas, the second bank is beginning to cycle out of phase.
It's fine. It, it's fine as it is.
Harmony of voices like a wind.
What was that? Who's doing that? Familiar Twelve, is there a fault? Is the core processor showing a fault?
12: Information unavailable, Sefor Alloran.
What the hell is that?
12: Unable to answer that, Sefor Alloran.
More glass breaking. Familiar voices speed up.
What? What is that?
Everything gets louder and Lomas screams.
The Tardis materialises, door opens.
Lovely.
Would you give it a chance?
Door closes.
No, really. It's lovely.
What's that smell?
Yes, that... lovely smell.
It's just dampness.
Smells like Venice.
And you'd know what Venice smells like because?
When I was in secondary, we went on a school trip to Venice.
What kind of school did you go to?
The kind that went on a school trip to Venice.
Of course you did.
Yeah, and Venice smelled like this. Wet, stony, and a bit like rubbish. Like bin day.
Though it pains me to admit it, Mister Hex has a keen nose in this particular regard. Glasst City does smell like Venice, on account of the canals. Now, can we get a move on?
Glasst City?
What?
You called this place Glasst City. I thought we were going to somewhere called Nocturne.
We are. And we are. This is Glasst City, on Nocturne. City, planet. Planet, city. Does that clear it up, or would you like a diagram?
All right, I'm not thick.
Er, 000, ah. Too much temptation, must tease Hex.
I'm not.
Of course not. You went to a fine school. It did trips to Venice. Best my school offered was day release to Pentonville.
Oh! Surprise me further.

(ahem) Anyway, it's just like we were saying the other way. This is the Doctor's way. He keeps us in the dark, keeps us baffled, drip-feeds us information on a need-to-know basis. That way he looks clever and we look stupid.
I don't do that, do I?
Yep.
Yeah, you do.
I think you like things to be a surprise. You like the grand reveal.
I don't.
You do.
You take us to places, but you don't tell us much about them.
Until it's too late.
Until it's much too late.
Or, or, you take us somewhere, and you do tell us something about it, but then it turns out to be a bit misleading.
I don't.
You do.
Like when?
When you took us to Breearos?
Breearos. Good example.
You said we were popping in so you could take your library books back.
We ended up staying for a fortnight whilst you negotiated the ceasefire in the Orbit Wars.
Ah, well...
Or, Tau Sartos.
Reason given for visit?
Reliable laundry service.
Actual reason?
To prevent the spawning of a Zylax swarm.
A task that involved more mucus than I was comfortable with.
Or, or Nydas Three.
Reason given for visit?
All right, if that's the way you feel. This was going to be a surprise. But if it's information you want...
Always useful.
Rarely provided.

Humph! Now, This is Glasst City, a human settlement on the planet Nocturne. The era you come from is about seven hundred and ninety years and three parsecs in that direction. There's a war on, and it's been going on for a long time, and it will continue to go on for a long time to come.
And we're here because?
Let's see. A war, going on a long time...
Mmm?
Nope. Just can't guess this time.
Actually, I've brought you here simply because it's one of my favourite places, ever. I thought you'd like to see it.
Harpsichord style music.
Up a full tone there. I wonder. Oh, something sits unhappily. Playback from notation seventeen.
A tune plays.
Oh, stop, stop, stop, stop, stop, stop. That's just too awful to listen to. Familiar? Fetch me some more port, would you? Familiar Ten, where are you?
10: My apologies, Sefor Thessinger. I was clearing the supper dishes. Your wish?

I wish for another glass of port. (doorbell) Oh! Who's visiting at this time of night? Go answer it. Forever coming and going. I don't know how I'm supposed to get a stroke done with all these interruptions.
You have a visitor, Sefor Thessinger. He apologises for the lateness of the hour.
Yes, yes. Who is it?
Sefior William Alloran.
Will Alloran? Good Lord.
Hello, sir.
Sounds just like Lomas.
Will. I don't believe my eyes. Will Alloran.
It's good to see you, sir.
And you, my boy, and you. Glory, how long has it been?
Eighteen months.
Eighteen months. My, my. Let me look at you in that... uniform. Very dashing. The War Department can spare you, then?
Most of me, sir.
So, what are you doing here?
Disability leave, actually. The left leg here, below the knee. Not the one I was born with.
Oh, Will. I had no idea.
No reason you should. It was months ago.
Well, it's... it's simply marvellous to see you. I've worried about you since the day you left.
I know you have.
And missed your company, of course.
How are you?
Oh, the same as ever. As you can see, surrounded by my papers, my instruments. A nest of creativity, scribbling away.
And the Great Mass?
Ah, well. Eluding me still. I have the core of it, but there's still some way to go. These things do not compose themselves overnight.
And how is my brother?
He... he's... Well, Lomas is ahead of his studies as usual, pushing to learn more as fast as I teach him. Just like you in that regard.
That's good.
And what of you? I suppose your duties have prevented you from extending your voice, or...
No. No, I haven't completely forgotten I work here. I've managed to compose a little. An idea or two. One can't help oneself, even at the front line.
Good. I'm glad to hear that. Play me something.
No. No. I haven't touched the keys in all that time.
Humour me.
Well, there, there is this refrain that I've been toying with, it's er
Plays.
Something like that.
That's very fine, Will.
It's very rough. I hope to develop it into something one day. A requiem, I think.
You should. It's very fine indeed.
Which leads us to the Far Renaissance.
The Far Renaissance.
That's what I said. I've always been fond of the human race. There's something about loss and suffering that brings out the best in it. There's a war going on, did I mention that?
Yes.
Particularly futile, particularly stalemated war against a particularly humourless species called the Foucoo. It's been going on for seventy years.
Seventy?
Mmm.
Why do they keep at it?
Pride. And of course, they don't recruit on the basis it will last decades.
Well, what do they say?
That it'll be all over by Christmas.
And this is one of your favourite places, why?

Out of adversity, wonder. I've seen it happen in a great number of cultures over the years. Poetry, fiction, painting, music. Art blossoms in response to and in defiance of the fact of war. Come up here, onto the bridge. See, up there? That's Tau Ceti. Riga. The yellow smudge of light, that's old Earth. Or it's neighbourhood at least. Oh, and over there Zeta Reticula, the Hessa Cloud, the Foucoo home system.
And where are we exactly?
Nocturne is smack in the middle. Soldiers pass through on their way to the front and come back this way when they've done, or dead.
That's grim.

It is. But it's also attracted to this city the greatest concentration of human artists and thinkers since the Florentine Renaissance. Right here, right now, and for a period of about thirty years, human art is flourishing in a way that it will do just a half a dozen times in the entire history of your race.
Your Far Renaissance?

That's what history will call it. It will produce the plays of Casto. Sinder's Odes. The Quantum Movement. Luminalism. All but one of Thessinger's Symphonies and his Great Mass. Shumack's Sculptures. The Zeitists. The novels of Elber Rocass.
Yeah, we get the idea.
I pay this place a visit whenever I get the chance. Oh, I have friends here. Would you like to meet them?
Okay.
Yeah, why not?
Then let's take a little walk to Ragpole's salon.
Music ends, applause.
Ah. Sefora Dillane.
Lothar. How are things tonight?
Oh, things, they're fine with me as ever. No... no Korbin tonight?
Not for weeks.
And Luke?
Too busy with his latest score to come drinking. I fear the joys of our youth are over. We're all getting too old.
Mmm, speak for yourself, Sehora. What say I fetch a bottle and join you for a while, mm? I can't have you sitting alone and forlorn. It would damage the reputation of my establishment.
Aren't you busy running your establishment?
It can run itself. Or at least the Familiars can. Oh, how goes your painting?
Well enough. I'm working on a series of studies. Shadow and light on the canal.
Oh, I look forward to a viewing. I... I've been busy with my latest epic, of course. The Muse does so like to stalk me. In fact, I er, well, I could read you a few stanzas?
That will surely lift your spirits, eh?
Oh, why, that would be... an unalloyed delight, Sefior Ragpole.

Well, if you insist. Ah, now. Yes, this. This is from the eighteenth stanza. Book nine. Lo! Inky black the night had turned, and inky black the storm, and inky black and midnight black, the soul that wrote this spurned. The soul that poured this...
Oberst Reeney.
What have you got, Familiar?
Anomaly at the city gate end of the central canal.
What kind of anomaly?
Unable to answer. Checking. Acoustic anomaly. Suggestion that it may be associated with atmospheric disturbances detected beyond the city limits this evening.

Show me the waveform. That looks like a storm front. There, west of the city. There was nothing on the forecast. Run it through the city defence net. It's been a long time since the Foucoo tried anything, but you never know.
At once, Oberst Reeney.
Nightwatch Sixteen, this is Reeney of the Overwatch.
[OC]: Go ahead, Oberst Reeney.
I've got a blip in your patch. You showing anything?
[OC]: Indeed, Oberst Reeney. A stray Familiar. It appears to have wandered in from the Veldts on autonomous function.
That all?
[OC]: Confirmed.
Okay. False alarm. Keep me posted.
And the years have come and gone, and inky black has fled. I'll see those words again my love, and see how bright they shone. And then, then I'll Know you midnight inks...
It's the worst poetry known to man.
Eh? Doctor. (laughs) Doctor! On my life, what a surprise.
Hello, Lothar.
Oh, this is wonderful. Wonderful to see you. Ha, ha! A night for celebration after all, eh Lilian?
Absolutely. A most timely arrival. Hello, Doctor.
Lilian, you look well.
Oh, I am. A little greyer. You however don't appear to have changed in the slightest. Which makes a change.
Ace, Hex, over here. Lothar Ragpole. Lilian Dillane. This is Hex, and this is Ace.
Hi.
Evening.
How absolutely delicious. Sefora Ace, I...
Just Ace.
Just Ace?
Unless you want something snapped off.
(laughs.) Glory be, Doctor! You've not brought along guests as feisty as this since Senora Jovanka.
And we all know how that evening ended.
Sit down. Sit down. Familiar, drinks here, if you please.
At once, Sefor Ragpole.
Nice robots. Hello.
Good evening, sir.
Why are they all girls? Aren't there any bloke bots?
Research apparently proved that people are more comfortable with the representation of the female form. Masculinity can be so threatening.
Hmm, sounds more like male chauvinism's still alive and well.
Hear, hear.
Don't get too familiar with the Familiars. A robot is a robot, whatever it looks like.
You've never been comfortable with them, have you, Doctor?
Too much that can go wrong. I've seen it before. So Lilian, how go things in Glasst?
The artists' enclave broods its way ever onwards, Doctor. Feuds and arguments, despondency and frustration. The universe turns about us pitiless. And the war, of course.
The war. I'm looking for the old faces. I see Gustav over there, and is that Octavia?
That's Octavia. We're not speaking. She's thrown in with the new cynics, and quite renounced post- pigmentism.
Imagine that.
What about Luke or Korbin?
Oh, too occupied with their work, Doctor. Too occupied to share the society of their fellows.
Ah, all work and no play, Doctor. It's bad for the soul. It breeds a... a distemper that quite inhibits the creation of art.
A distemper you've never suffered from, Lothar.
Merciful heavens, no. The Muse does so like to stalk me. My establishment is of course the finest antidote to such distemper.
Sefor Ragpole's establishment has been serving the artistic enclave of Glasst for twenty years.
I see.
Serving them right, more like.
And not for much longer, I fear. Restrictions, tightened curfews.
Oh, anyone would think there's a war on.

There's a new Oberst at the City Overwatch. I think she's got something to prove. Security is so tight these days. This reunion itself will be short and sweet. The law expects me to lock up in half an hour.
Well, someone had better get them in, then.
Hear, hear.
What does the law say about private parties after hours?
Well, it... What have you got in mind, Doctor?
Korbin still Keeps his rooms at Tanza's Palace?
He does indeed.
Then I suggest we take ourselves over there, for the good of his soul.
A capital notion. I'll round up the usual suspects, and a crate or two.
I'll walk there via Commune Square, and see if I can rouse Luke from his lodgings. And might I trouble someone to escort me? The canal pavements are very dark.
Yeah. I'll walk with you.
How charming. Thank you.
This is very kind of you.
No problem. I've only just arrived, and I like to get the feel of a place.
And what does this place feel like, Sefor Hex?
Venice.
I'm sorry?
Er, doesn't matter. So, you've known the Doctor a long time?
Oh, it's been my good fortune to while away the hours with him on many of his visits over the years. He has a unique understanding of my pursuit for perfection in my art.
Right. Cool. So, where are we going again?
To Sefor Moray's lodgings.

Another old friend of the Doctor's. We can, I hope, persuade him to come along to the party. He's temperamental at best, and rarely likes admitting people who haven't called ahead. He'll be in such a bad mood. I love it.
Doorbell. Door opened.
Good evening. Sefor Moray is not at home to visitors. Who calls at Sefhor Moray's house? Who calls at Sefor Moray's house? Who call...
The Familiar gets confused, glass breaks, furniture crashes.
What was that?
The wind, or...
That wasn't the wind. I've never heard anything like that before.
Music. Sound. Art.
You what?
My dear, everything around us is art in some form or other. The buildings, the sky, the sound of music, or a brush in paint, then on canvas. Even the, the...
The?
Not to worry.
The war. We're you going to say the war?
Now, Luke's place is just down here. The light's there, you see?
For a man who doesn't like unexpected company, leaving his front door open like that is...
Oh! But he wouldn't. Oh, my! What's happened?
Hello?
Luke, Luke, are you there?
A man screams.
Luke! Luke!
Stay back! Can't you feel that? There's something here. Something with us.
By all that's holy, I...
Stay back! Lilian, stay back!

FAMILIAR: 12: (they all sound the same) Your wish, Sefor Alloran?
LOMAS: Assist Sefor Merickson with that coupling.

LOMAS: Can we have quiet, please? Please, quiet! Main power on. My friends, we couldn't have asked for a more beautiful evening. The sunset, the fading light against the city walls. BIX: Yes, Lomas.

LOMAS: What? What is that?
ACE: Lovely.
DOCTOR: Would you give it a chance?
ACE: No, really. It's lovely.
HEX: What's that smell?
ACE: Yes, that... lovely smell.
DOCTOR: It's just dampness.
HEX: Smells like Venice.

HEX: When I was in secondary, we went on a school trip to Venice.
ACE: What kind of school did you go to?
HEX: The kind that went on a school trip to Venice.
ACE: Of course you did.
HEX: Yeah, and Venice smelled like this. Wet, stony, and a bit like rubbish. Like bin day.
DOCTOR: Though it pains me to admit it, Mister Hex has a keen nose in this particular regard. Glasst City does smell like Venice, on account of the canals. Now, can we get a move on?

DOCTOR: What?
HEX: You called this place Glasst City. I thought we were going to somewhere called Nocturne.
DOCTOR: We are. And we are. This is Glasst City, on Nocturne. City, planet. Planet, city. Does that clear it up, or would you like a diagram?
HEX: All right, I'm not thick.
ACE: Er, 000, ah. Too much temptation, must tease Hex.
HEX: I'm not.

HEX: Oh! Surprise me further.

ACE: Yep.
HEX: Yeah, you do.

DOCTOR: I don't.

HEX: You take us to places, but you don't tell us much about them.
ACE: Until it's too late.
HEX: Until it's much too late.

DOCTOR: I don't.
HEX: You do.
DOCTOR: Like when?
ACE: When you took us to Breearos?
HEX: Breearos. Good example.
ACE: You said we were popping in so you could take your library books back.
HEX: We ended up staying for a fortnight whilst you negotiated the ceasefire in the Orbit Wars.

HEX: Reason given for visit?
ACE: Reliable laundry service.

HEX: A task that involved more mucus than I was comfortable with.

ACE: Always useful.
HEX: Rarely provided.

HEX: Nope. Just can't guess this time.

KORBIN: Up a full tone there. I wonder. Oh, something sits unhappily. Playback from notation seventeen.
KORBIN: Oh, stop, stop, stop, stop, stop, stop. That's just too awful to listen to. Familiar? Fetch me some more port, would you? Familiar Ten, where are you?
FAMILIAR: 10: My apologies, Sefor Thessinger. I was clearing the supper dishes. Your wish?
KORBIN: I wish for another glass of port. (doorbell) Oh! Who's visiting at this time of night? Go answer it. Forever coming and going. I don't know how I'm supposed to get a stroke done with all these interruptions.
FAMILIAR: You have a visitor, Sefor Thessinger. He apologises for the lateness of the hour.
KORBIN: Yes, yes. Who is it?
FAMILIAR: Sefior William Alloran.
KORBIN: Will Alloran? Good Lord.
WILL: Hello, sir.
KORBIN: Will. I don't believe my eyes. Will Alloran.
WILL: It's good to see you, sir.
KORBIN: And you, my boy, and you. Glory, how long has it been?
WILL: Eighteen months.
KORBIN: Eighteen months. My, my. Let me look at you in that... uniform. Very dashing. The War Department can spare you, then?
WILL: Most of me, sir.
KORBIN: So, what are you doing here?
WILL: Disability leave, actually. The left leg here, below the knee. Not the one I was born with.
KORBIN: Oh, Will. I had no idea.
WILL: No reason you should. It was months ago.
KORBIN: Well, it's... it's simply marvellous to see you. I've worried about you since the day you left.
WILL: I know you have.
KORBIN: And missed your company, of course.

WILL: That's good.
KORBIN: And what of you? I suppose your duties have prevented you from extending your voice, or...
WILL: No. No, I haven't completely forgotten I work here. I've managed to compose a little. An idea or two. One can't help oneself, even at the front line.

WILL: No. No. I haven't touched the keys in all that time.
KORBIN: Humour me.
WILL: Well, there, there is this refrain that I've been toying with, it's er
WILL: Something like that.
KORBIN: That's very fine, Will.
WILL: It's very rough. I hope to develop it into something one day. A requiem, I think.
KORBIN: You should. It's very fine indeed.
