ACE: I was worried about you.
WILL: No need. I'm fine. You should go.
ACE: Not until you explain. Back at the caf you said that you were responsible for Moray's death. And your brother. What did you mean? Please, Will. I just want to help.
WILL: (sighs) All right. Months ago, before I left for the war, I discovered something in the Archives. Ancient alien scripts found on a distant planet. The archaeologists who unearthed them didn't understand their true significance. Not their field of expertise, I suppose.
ACE: But you understood them.
WILL: Yes, eventually. Bio-harmonics. Completely new kind of music. Pure and raw. Beautiful, but potentially deadly.
ACE: Deadly? The sound that Hex heard at Moray's.
WILL: I realised that I'd stumbled across dangerous knowledge. Too dangerous to just be left for someone else to find, so I erased it from the Archives, and I thought that was an end to it.
ACE: But it wasn't, was it? Your brother...
WILL: Yes. The idiot. He was always trying to compete with me, trying to go one better. Without me knowing, he made a copy of my research on the Ulanti. I discovered what he'd done the day before I was due to ship out. We had a blazing row and I made him swear that he wouldn't do anything with it. I told him how dangerous it could be. Well, he obviously ignored me. Did what he wanted just like he always did, and now... now it's too late, he's... he's let something terrible loose and it's killed him.
ACE: You can't be certain of that.
WILL: Yes. I am, I Know it. What Hex and Lilian found at Moray's proves it.
ACE: (sighs) I think the Doctor suspected something like this. He didn't want to say anything to you till he was sure. We should go back to the Palace and talk to him, tell him everything.
WILL: What good will that do? It's too late. It's out there now and it can't be stopped.
ACE: Don't underestimate the Doctor. He's good at defying the odds.
WILL: If you really believe that, you can give him this.
ACE: What is it?
WILL: My data-pad. All my compositions are on it, and the Ulanti research notes. It's everything that Lomas copied.
ACE: Thank you. This could be important. But I'm sure the Doctor would still like to speak to you.
WILL: No. I'm waiting here.
HEX: Any sign of them?
RAGPOLE: No. There's no one around. The streets are empty. I went as far as the Lazlo Collection, and that's been shut for the night.
HEX: I asked in an arcade back there. It was just closing too.
RAGPOLE: Oh.
HEX: The owner said a girl fitting Ace's description had come in looking for a soldier. She headed off towards the School Of Music about an hour ago.
RAGPOLE: Oh well, that's... that just down here. Do... do you hear something, Sefor Hex?
HEX: No.
RAGPOLE: I could have sworn I... Yes, there.
HEX: I know that sound.
RAGPOLE: You do?
HEX: I know that sound. At Luke Moray's house.
RAGPOLE: Well, perhaps we should get away from here.
HEX: Come on!
RAGPOLE: No, you're mad. We've got to go!
HEX: I'm not going anywhere without Ace.
RAGPOLE: No, Hex. Come back, Sefor Hex!
ACE: Is that Moray too?
WILL: No. No. This is me.
ACE: It's beautiful. Oh, it's getting colder in here. I think we should go, Will.
WILL: Get out, Ace. Go find the Doctor, before it's too late.
ACE: What was that? Will, I'm scared, and I don't know why.
WILL: It's coming. Get out, Ace! Run!
ACE: This is what you were hoping would happen, isn't it? You wanted it to come here. To find you!
WILL: Please go, Ace, it'll kill you.
ACE: It'll kill you as well. Don't do this!
WILL: I need to feel it. It killed him and I need to touch it!
ACE: Will! Get out!

elements.text: [Part Four]
Run. Run!
Will, don't get near it.
Piano being destroyed.
Will!
Go to the door, now!
Will screams.
Ace?
Will!
Ace!
Will!
Ace?
(drowsy) Doctor.
Don't try to get up. You've had a close call.
Will's dead.
Yes. I know he is.
He knew about the noise.
He discovered it, didn't he?
Yes. But he knew it was dangerous. Tried to cover it up.
But somehow Lomas got his hands on it, and paid the price.
He's dead as well.
I'm afraid so.
(sighs) Will knew he was. (sighs) He wanted you to have this.
His research on the Ulanti bio-harmonics. Thank you. This could help save the lives of everyone on Nocturne.
Good.
Ace, I... I'm sorry.
About Will?
Yes of course. But more than that. I know you and Thomas Hector were teasing, but you were right. I've got a terrible habit of not telling you enough.
What?

You said it yourself? I take you somewhere, and I don't tell you why. Or I don't tell you everything. Or I only tell you everything when it's too late. I'm sorry for that. In my defence, I only do it to protect you.
I know, Professor.
I promise, I only brought you here because I thought you'd like it. I didn't expect we'd get involved in anything.
You never do.

From the moment Luke Moray was killed I had an idea about what was wrong here. I should have told you. I should have just told you. I put you in danger because I didn't. In the future, I'll make sure I tell you.
I thought this was the future. If you had told me, Doctor, would Will be alive?

I don't know. I do know that William Alloran, Thessinger's greatest and most gifted pupil, died young before he could fulfil his promise. I always assumed he died in the war. That was why I was surprised to see him back here. Perhaps I should have guessed when things started to go off the rail.
I'm sorry too. I know you really like this time, this place. That's why you keep coming back here. I'm
really sorry it's been spoiled by this.
So am I. I'd better go and sort it out then, hadn't I?
How is she, Doctor?
Shaken.
I'll sit with her a while.
Yes, I think that's a good idea.
So, Doctor?
Calm yourself, Oberst. Thanks to Will Alloran we now have the information we need.
And what does it say?

You'll have to give me a moment. This material's quite dense. Ah yes. Now, this is the stuff. Material from various cosmographical mission reports, two hundred years old. The Ulanti and their homeworld .
I've never heard of the Ulanti.
That's hardly surprising. They've been dead these last two million years. But in their time, they knew how to write a damn good tune.
(gasps) Oh, it's you.
Dreaming?
Nightmare. Will and that... thing.
Yeah, I know. I'm sorry, Ace. I know you liked him.
He knew what was going to happen, you know. He wanted the noise to find him. He was deliberately baiting it, trying to draw it in.
How do you mean?
I'm not sure. I think it was the music. It was attracted by Will's playing.
But why would he do that? I mean, he could have got you killed as well. Nearly did.
No. He tried to make me leave, but I wouldn't. He blamed himself for what happened to his brother. Guilt. He felt responsible for that noise. Oh, I should never have told him about Moray.
Oh, don't blame yourself. He'd have found out eventually.
Yeah. Yeah, I guess so.
(kiss) Sleep well, Ace. I'm here for you.
Who are these Ulanti you keep mentioning?
The Ulanti, long extinct now, developed a technique called bio-harmonics. To put it simply, they used their own planet as a musical instrument.
I beg your pardon?
Fascinating.
The devices they used were complex machines. An arrangement of core processors, reflectors, synthesisers and resonators.
This is all nonsense.

Not at all. The Ulanti used their devices to create music that was an expression of their own world. A natural melody produced by the biological rhythms of their own ecosystem. And that's what Lomas Alloran tried to do here on Nocturne.
That's beautiful.
For the Ulanti, yes. Their homeworld was a serene and unspoilt wilderness. Their music was sublime. But Nocturne is not quite so pretty.
Oh, pure, living music.
I've heard enough, Doctor. Please. The killings in this city are being committed by, what, a tune?

Lomas unleashed something, Oberst. He tapped into the essence of Nocturne and gave it a voice to cry out with. The pain of this place, the fear, the darkness, he manifested it. He made it real, he gave it form. And it's growing in power even as we speak.
I can't believe we're just sitting here swallowing this nonsense.
I find it quite compelling, actually .
But how do we stop it, Doctor?
Thanks to Will Alloran's research, I'm sure that I can rig up something that will do the trick.
Oh well, thank all that's holy for that. That's the best news we've heard all day.
Not quite. Our real problem is not stopping it, but finding it. What we really need is...
Bait?
Exactly, Mister Hex. Did you have something in mind?
How about music? Ace said that Will was deliberately trying to attract the thing, with music.
Yeah.
It's attracted to music?
Perhaps it has good taste.
Everyone's a critic these days.
Every victim so far has been an artist. Not just an artist, but an artist in the act of making art.
It is true that all the murders have been in the Artists' Enclave.
This thing, this phenomenon, is drawn to art and beauty. It's pulled in by the antithesis of itself.
So, we can use poetry and music as a lure.
And then what?
A trap. It'd be very makeshift. I'll need to try and duplicate the devices Lomas set up originally.
All right, Doctor. This is incredible, but...
But you've seen the light ?
What do we do?
You've got contacts, Oberst. A southern pool in the city. This is what we need here. Look. A processor will be the hardest part to procure.
All right. I'll get on to the War Department.
Hex, Ragpole, go with her. Resonators too. Whatever you can find. I'll have to reconfigure to Ulanti specifications.
On our way.
I'll clear the work room for you, Doctor.
Excellent. Thank you, Korbin.
Doctor.
Lilian.
Does it really have to be destroyed?
But Lilian, it almost killed you. It did kill Luke and the Alloran brothers.
Yes, I, I know, and that's terrible of course. But if it really is living art...
Put it in a frame? Stand it on a plinth? Install it in a museum?
Well...
No, Lilian. Even if it were possible, this particular masterpiece is deadly. No art, however perfect, should be valued over life.
No. No, I suppose not.
There's no alternative. It must be destroyed.
Thunder, heavy rain.
A filthy night, Doctor. Quite a storm.
No, not natural either. Hmm. I think the local climate patterns are being disturbed by the gathering power of this thing.
We're still calling it a thing?
We're still calling it a thing.
And it's getting stronger, you think?
Hmm, the longer it's out there, the more it draws on the environment. It was powerful to begin with. It's getting frighteningly powerful now. If it's not stopped...
Yes?
Who knows? Today, Glasst City, tomorrow, the whole of Nocturne. And the day after that...
That's encouraging. How's it coming? You've certainly made a mess of my workroom.
Pass me that probe.
This one?
No, the smaller gauge one. Thank you. How do you feel about being bait, then?
Beats running around in the rain, I imagine. What should I play?
Anything. Anything tuneful, harmonious. Spiritual music. Plainsong. Any Great Mass you happen to know.
Door opens.
Reeney.
Good evening, Oberst. Try not to drip on the carpet.

I've managed to get the rest of the equipment you asked for. This is part of it. Hex and Ragpole are following with the rest. I got everything except a loop modulator. One of my techs suggested a pulse compressor might do instead.
Pulse compressor will be fine.
Good, because that's what you've got. Are you ready?
Another ten, fifteen minutes with any luck. What about you?

I've got the curfew in place and Nightwatch patrols out on every cross-street from the Palladio to Saint Olaf's. I've also issued an injunction on all music, poetry reading and forms of artistic expression. But I can't guarantee nobody's going to start practicing the piccolo in their attic.
That should starve it, bring it here to the Palace, towards the bait.
Hello.
I also brought these communicators you asked for.
Good. Hand them out to everyone.
Why?
Because we all need beaters.
Beaters?
My dear Oberst, have you never hunted a tune before?
Are we waiting in the right place?
The atrium. That's what the Doctor said.
Old Earth. It's quite foul outside.
There's the Doctor now.
All set?
Each of you, take one of these communicators.
Did you bring the pots and pans?
Yep. Er, stuff from the kitchen. Why, what's it for?

Korbin's setting the bait upstairs. Sweet music to lure it into the Palace compound, but it may need a little persuasion. Harsh noises, discordant sounds. It will be repelled by those as much as it will be drawn by art. We must spread out and make as much noise as we can around the edges of Tanza's Palace once we're sure it's in. Lilian, Lothar, you go anti-clockwise with Hex. Oberst and I will go the other way.
Couldn't we get the Familiars to do this instead?
I've asked Korbin to shut down all the Palace Familiars. We don't want a repeat of what happened out on the Veldt, do we?
Er, no. No, good point. But what happens if beating a saucepan with a wooden spoon doesn't work either?
Improvise. Shout, stamp your feet.
Read it some of your poetry.
Hey!
Actually, that's not a bad idea. Sorry, Lothar.
What? I don't have to stand for this.
I know it's hardly the time or the place to get into this, Lothar, but your verse is abominable.
But, but really? It is?
Truly shocking.
But ... Oh, but the Muse. It does so like to stalk me.
Let's hope it's just the Muse.
My point is anything like that will do. Crude noises, doggerel, anything without artistic merit.
Right. Let's get to it.
Best of luck, everybody. Nobody whistle while they work.
[OC]: Korbin, can you hear me?
Er, yes. Yes, Doctor, I can hear you.
[OC]: We're on our way. Start playing bait, if you will.
As you like, Doctor.
Beethoven's Moonlight Sonata. Door opens.
Ah! Oh, that's nice. I know that.
The Doctor told me to play bait. I thought, better still, play Beethoven.
Ha, ha.
Shouldn't you be resting?
Mmn,, probably. This is the Doctor's trap?
Apparently.
Looks complicated.
Yes it does.
How does it work?
He didn't tell me.
Well, how do you turn it on?
He didn't tell me that either.
He's really got to stop doing that.
I'm sorry?
Oh, doesn't matter.
I assumed the idea was that he'd get here in time to turn it on.
As usual, the plan is seamless.
Music stops.
Look, perhaps you'd better go and rest. The Doctor won't forgive me if I let you overdo it.
Oh, can I just stay here on the couch? I won't get in the way.
All right.
He resumes playing.
See anything?
Not a thing.
Let's walk through the cloisters.
Okay.
Is my poetry really that bad?
Dear Lothar, you're going to have to put that aside for a moment. We've got work to do.
Hey. Did you hear that?
Well, just the wind, surely.
Yeah. I think it was just the wind. Come on.
This is the moment, then?
What moment?
Well, if I was right all along, and you are the real danger here, this is the moment when you get me on my own to do away with me.
Just hold onto your saucepan, woman, and concentrate on the task.
Maybe it doesn't like the rain.
Maybe it doesn't. No. Listen.
You're right. Something moved.
Behind those doors. Put that away. Guns are no use.
I like guns.
I don't.
I prefer them to, you know, death?
It's coming.
Door opens with a creak.
Your wish, Sefiora?
Oh. One of Thessinger's damn Familiars. They were supposed to have all been shut down.
Hush, Oberst.
We'll be jumping at shadows if they're just roaming about. We...
Shh, Oberst. Can't you hear? It's right outside.
[OC]: Hex?
Doctor?
[OC]: We think we've spotted it. We think it's moving your way.
There's no sign of it, but we'll take a look. Do you see anything?
No.
Not a thing.
No, wait! It may be my imagination, or just the simple nature of suggestion...
No, it's not. Your heart's beating fast, right? You feel scared for no reason?
I feel... oh. I feel terrified suddenly. Can we go?
No we can't. Much as I'd like to. It must be close. It's all I can do to force my feet to work.
No, I... I think I might have to run away .
Where is it? Where is it?
There! It's right there. Doctor, we've found it. Doctor? Something's up with the communicator. Come on, make a noise. (hitting the pan) Come on!
Oh, it doesn't like that, does it?
No, it doesn't. Come on, Ragpole!
Is it safe to look yet?
Bang your pot, man!
Hex, it's still coming this way.
I know.
Hex!
Oh, what the... (ahem) Lo, my love...
They've found it.
Come on.
They're through here, but the door's locked. We'll have to find another way around...
Gunshot.
Ah!
Guns are useful sometimes. For blowing locks out, as an example.
Door opens.
Hex, Lilian, where are you? Lothar.
Doctor.
Are you all right?
It just kept coming, right at us.
What happened?
Ragpole drove it off.
How?
... I read it a few lines.
Good man. Where's Lilian?
She ran after it. God, she can certainly move for an old girl.
Which way?
It... it seemed to pull away into the Palace.
Heading for the bait. Heading for Korbin and Ace. And the communicators are dead. Oh, Lilian.
Doctor!
Doctor, wait.
There's been no word from them. Is this communicator thing working, do you suppose? Sefora Ace? Ah. Ah. You sleep tight, young lady. (music ends) What next, I wonder? Any requests?
Hey. That's Will's.
I thought you were asleep.
Will wrote that, that piece you're playing.
Yes.
Don't you dare take it. Don't you dare steal it from him just because he's dead.
My dear young lady, I am quite aware of what it is, and I have no intention of...
Crash! They cry out.
Oh, glory! I don't want to be bait any more!
Get away from it. Over by the windows.
Korbin! We can't let this be destroyed. We must find another way.
Lilian, get out!
Ace! Ace! Don't let Lilian near the equipment. My word, you're an ugly thing, aren't you? I almost feel sorry for you. The unremitting pain.
Doctor!
Ace, hit the switch. Ace, hit the switch!
Which one?
Oh, for the love of... The great big red one!
No! You can't kill the music.
Lilian! No. Let... let me... let me go!
Now, Ace. Do it now!
Power builds. Boom. Glass breaking. Thunder outside.
Oh. Has, has it gone?
Yes, forever. No thanks to Lilian.
Is she dead?
No. A broken arm, I think, and concussion. She'll be all right, but she doesn't deserve to be.
When I hit the switch , what was that sound?
An acoustic feedback, modulated to first echo and then cancel out the harmonics of that thing, thus blowing it apart.
So in layman's terms?
Call it the Charge of the Leitmotif.
Hah. Very droll, Doctor.
Come on, let's get Lilian to the infirmary.
Ah, Senor Thessinger. An unexpected pleasure. You, er, not composing tonight?
Ah, Ragpole. Do you know, I haven't felt so inspired in years. Odd really, considering all that's happened.
Hmm. And yet here you are, drinking alone in my salon.
Time to reflect. To remember the good times. I had wondered if the Doctor might be here.
I found this note pushed under the salon door this evening.
Ah. (reads) Had to leave due to unforeseen circumstances. Take care until I drop in again. P.S. Don't be too hard on Lilian. Hmm. Will you join me for a glass of something, Ragpole?
I'd be delighted, Korbin.
So, how's your latest epic coming along, then?
Ragpole sighs.
Well, the rain's stopped.
We should have said goodbye at least.
I left them a note. And I hate goodbyes.
About Thessinger...
Korbin Thessinger is about to complete the last great work of his career, his Great Mass. A work that will be celebrated as a masterpiece for as long as humanity persists.
But...

I never told you its subtitle. Korbin is very specific in his score. From a theme by William Alloran, my pupil and my better. Posterity will assume that Korbin was moved to write his Great Mass after the death of his favourite pupil in the Foucoo War.
Will's name will live on.
His name, and his refrain.
You're never coming back here, are you, Doctor?
Never is a long word, Hex.
But are you? I mean, it's been one of your favourite places, and now that's tarnished. It's the end of an era.
That's the splendid thing about time travel. It's never the end of an era. I'll be back, sooner or later. When it's quieter.
Tardis door opens.
Doctor? Are you coming? What are you thinking about?
Take but degree away, untune that string, and hark what discord follows.
What's that? Another of Ragpole's?
Thomas Hector Schofield, that's Shakespeare.
Yeah Hex, didn't you learn anything at school?
I must have been off that day. Or in Venice.
They laugh. Tardis door closes, the Tardis dematerialises.

WILL: Go to the door, now!
HEX: Ace?
ACE: Will!
HEX: Ace!
ACE: Will!
DOCTOR: Ace?
ACE: (drowsy) Doctor.
DOCTOR: Don't try to get up. You've had a close call.
ACE: Will's dead.
DOCTOR: Yes. I know he is.
ACE: He knew about the noise.
DOCTOR: He discovered it, didn't he?
ACE: Yes. But he knew it was dangerous. Tried to cover it up.
DOCTOR: But somehow Lomas got his hands on it, and paid the price.

ACE: Good.
DOCTOR: Ace, I... I'm sorry.
ACE: About Will?
DOCTOR: Yes of course. But more than that. I know you and Thomas Hector were teasing, but you were right. I've got a terrible habit of not telling you enough.
ACE: What?
DOCTOR: You said it yourself? I take you somewhere, and I don't tell you why. Or I don't tell you everything. Or I only tell you everything when it's too late. I'm sorry for that. In my defence, I only do it to protect you.
ACE: I know, Professor.
DOCTOR: I promise, I only brought you here because I thought you'd like it. I didn't expect we'd get involved in anything.

DOCTOR: I don't know. I do know that William Alloran, Thessinger's greatest and most gifted pupil, died young before he could fulfil his promise. I always assumed he died in the war. That was why I was surprised to see him back here. Perhaps I should have guessed when things started to go off the rail.
ACE: I'm sorry too. I know you really like this time, this place. That's why you keep coming back here. I'm
ACE: really sorry it's been spoiled by this.
DOCTOR: So am I. I'd better go and sort it out then, hadn't I?
HEX: How is she, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Shaken.
HEX: I'll sit with her a while.
DOCTOR: Yes, I think that's a good idea.
REENEY: So, Doctor?

REENEY: And what does it say?

REENEY: I've never heard of the Ulanti.
DOCTOR: That's hardly surprising. They've been dead these last two million years. But in their time, they knew how to write a damn good tune.
ACE: (gasps) Oh, it's you.
HEX: Dreaming?
ACE: Nightmare. Will and that... thing.
HEX: Yeah, I know. I'm sorry, Ace. I know you liked him.
ACE: He knew what was going to happen, you know. He wanted the noise to find him. He was deliberately baiting it, trying to draw it in.
HEX: How do you mean?
ACE: I'm not sure. I think it was the music. It was attracted by Will's playing.
HEX: But why would he do that? I mean, he could have got you killed as well. Nearly did.
ACE: No. He tried to make me leave, but I wouldn't. He blamed himself for what happened to his brother. Guilt. He felt responsible for that noise. Oh, I should never have told him about Moray.
HEX: Oh, don't blame yourself. He'd have found out eventually.
ACE: Yeah. Yeah, I guess so.
HEX: (kiss) Sleep well, Ace. I'm here for you.
REENEY: Who are these Ulanti you keep mentioning?
DOCTOR: The Ulanti, long extinct now, developed a technique called bio-harmonics. To put it simply, they used their own planet as a musical instrument.
KORBIN: I beg your pardon?
RAGPOLE: Fascinating.
DOCTOR: The devices they used were complex machines. An arrangement of core processors, reflectors, synthesisers and resonators.
REENEY: This is all nonsense.
DOCTOR: Not at all. The Ulanti used their devices to create music that was an expression of their own world. A natural melody produced by the biological rhythms of their own ecosystem. And that's what Lomas Alloran tried to do here on Nocturne.
LILIAN: That's beautiful.
DOCTOR: For the Ulanti, yes. Their homeworld was a serene and unspoilt wilderness. Their music was sublime. But Nocturne is not quite so pretty.
LILIAN: Oh, pure, living music.
REENEY: I've heard enough, Doctor. Please. The killings in this city are being committed by, what, a tune?
DOCTOR: Lomas unleashed something, Oberst. He tapped into the essence of Nocturne and gave it a voice to cry out with. The pain of this place, the fear, the darkness, he manifested it. He made it real, he gave it form. And it's growing in power even as we speak.
REENEY: I can't believe we're just sitting here swallowing this nonsense.
LILIAN: I find it quite compelling, actually .
KORBIN: But how do we stop it, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Thanks to Will Alloran's research, I'm sure that I can rig up something that will do the trick.
RAGPOLE: Oh well, thank all that's holy for that. That's the best news we've heard all day.
DOCTOR: Not quite. Our real problem is not stopping it, but finding it. What we really need is...
HEX: Bait?
DOCTOR: Exactly, Mister Hex. Did you have something in mind?
HEX: How about music? Ace said that Will was deliberately trying to attract the thing, with music.
DOCTOR: Yeah.
KORBIN: It's attracted to music?
LILIAN: Perhaps it has good taste.
RAGPOLE: Everyone's a critic these days.
DOCTOR: Every victim so far has been an artist. Not just an artist, but an artist in the act of making art.
REENEY: It is true that all the murders have been in the Artists' Enclave.
DOCTOR: This thing, this phenomenon, is drawn to art and beauty. It's pulled in by the antithesis of itself.
REENEY: So, we can use poetry and music as a lure.
KORBIN: And then what?
DOCTOR: A trap. It'd be very makeshift. I'll need to try and duplicate the devices Lomas set up originally.
REENEY: All right, Doctor. This is incredible, but...
DOCTOR: But you've seen the light ?
REENEY: What do we do?
DOCTOR: You've got contacts, Oberst. A southern pool in the city. This is what we need here. Look. A processor will be the hardest part to procure.
REENEY: All right. I'll get on to the War Department.
DOCTOR: Hex, Ragpole, go with her. Resonators too. Whatever you can find. I'll have to reconfigure to Ulanti specifications.
HEX: On our way.
KORBIN: I'll clear the work room for you, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Excellent. Thank you, Korbin.
LILIAN: Doctor.
DOCTOR: Lilian.
